title: ‘We are all in denial’: Le Scouarnec trial draws little media attention despite outcry
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: A feminist group in France working to combat sexual violence spoke to FRANCE 24 about the case of former French surgeon Joël Le Scouarnec, who is accused of sexually abusing hundreds of his patients, many of them children. The case is due to conclude this week. However, it has received far less publicity in France and worldwide than the recent Gisèle Pelicot trial, prompting questions about why this is the case.

title: End of 'bromance'? Papers react to spat between Trump and Putin
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: PRESS REVIEW – Tuesday, May 27: First, the tit-for-tat between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin after Russia's assault on Kyiv continues to make headlines. Also, Israeli papers are divided on how to cover the most recent Jerusalem marches. And, Namibia will be celebrating their first ever Remembrance Day to commemorate the genocide of the Herero and Nama people. Next, Eritrea's national football team will be playing its first game since January 2020. Finally, Brigitte Macron's shove makes waves in the papers.

title: Ukraine: Germany says allies scrap range limits on arms to Kyiv
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Germany's Chancellor Friedrich Merz said on Tuesday that the war in Ukraine is expected to persist due to Russia's reluctance to enter negotiations. For more, FRANCE 24's correspondent, Emmanuelle Chaze.

title: King Charles to deliver key speech amid Trump annexation threats on Canada
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: King Charles III is to outline new Prime Minister Mark Carney's government priorities in a speech in the Canadian Parliament. The move widely seen as a show of support for Canada in the face of annexation threats by U.S. President Donald Trump. The kind is the head of state in Canada, which is a member of the British Commonwealth of former colonies. Carney saying the visit speaks to the “vitality of our constitutional monarchy and our distinct identity.” Caroline Baum reports.

title: EU launches investigation into four porn platforms over risks to children
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: The European Union on Tuesday began an investigation into four online porn platforms accused of not doing enough to prevent children from accessing sexually explicit content.

title: France's National Assembly to vote on bill legalising assisted dying
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: France's lower house of parliament is set to vote Tuesday on a bill that would allow adults suffering from incurable illnesses to voluntarily end their life by taking a lethal substance prescribed by medical practitioners. A 2023 report indicated that a majority of French citizens support legalising end-of-life options.

title: French parliament to vote on assisted dying: Patients share their stories
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: French deputies are set to vote Tuesday on a controversial bill regarding end-of-life options before it moves to the Senate. The proposed “right to aid in dying” has divided politicians and healthcare professionals and reignited heated bioethical debates. In this report from France 2, palliative care workers and patients share their views on the matter.

title: Eye on Africa: In South Africa lesser flamingo loose breeding site
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: South Africa's Kampfers dam used to be one of only 4 breeding sites for lesser flamingos on the continent. But a recent series of sewage spills have poisoned its waters and the pink birds have now become a rare sighting there.

title: Eye on Africa: In Kenya, bictcoin drives green energy production
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Kenya has been producing more electricity than it's needs and now, a new industry is stepping in to make use of the surplus. That's cryptocurrency mining.Using mobile bitcoin farms, companies are converting otherwise wasted energy into digital currency. Supporters call it a win-win, but questions remain about whether this new use of energy will benefit the country as a whole. Clément Di Roma and Olivia Bizot report.

title: Two years since Ugandan Anti-Homosexuality Act became law
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: It's been two years since Uganda passed one of the world's harshest anti gay laws and Human rights watch is now reporting that since it came into force authorities in the country have comitted widespread discrimination and violence against lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people. For more, the senior Africa researcher at Human Rights Watch, Oryem Nyeko.

title: French parliament to vote on assisted dying: Patients share their stories
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: French deputies are set to vote Tuesday on a controversial bill regarding end-of-life options before it moves to the Senate. The proposed “right to aid in dying” has divided politicians and healthcare professionals and reignited heated bioethical debates. In this report from France 2, palliative care workers and patients share their views on the matter.

title: US-backed group says it has begun Gaza aid distribution after director quits over independence fears
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, a controversial aid group backed by the US and Israel, said on Monday it had began distributing food in the devastated Gaza Strip. The group's executive director resigned Sunday over fears the aid rollout would not be able to adhere to standards of "humanity, neutrality, impartiality, and independence".

title: European leaders push Brussels for progress in trade talks with US
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Countries including Italy, Ireland and France want the EU to fast-track negotiations with the Trump administration to avoid US tariffs. The ASEAN group of SE Asian nations meets with China and the Gulf Cooperation Council in a bid to hedge against growing trade uncertainty. And, France makes arrests after a series of violent kidnapping aimed at extorting cryptocurrency moguls.

title: French farmers protest against amendments filed by opposition lawmakers
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: French farmers have been disrupting highway traffic around Paris and have rallied in front of the French parliament. They are protesting against amendments filed by opposition lawmakers to a bill that they say would help them by loosening environmental regulations on farming including for example re authorising a banned pesticide used in sugar beet cultivation. Environmentalists though say it is harmful to bees. Antonia Kerrigan reports.

title: Merz anticipates prolonged Ukraine war due to Russia's reluctance for talks
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Germany’s new chancellor says his country and other major allies, including France, are no longer imposing any range restrictions on weapons supplied to Ukraine as it fights the Russian invasion. August Hakkenson reports.

title: EU staff condemn 'inaction that resulted in the full-scale invasion of' Gaza
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: "EU inaction has contributed to the environment of unaccountability that resulted in the full-scale invasion of the Gaza Strip taking place at this moment," says a group of EU staff called EU staff for peace. For more, FRANCE 24's International Affairs Editor, Philip Turle.

title: Spain demands an arms embargo to compel the Gaza War's termination.
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Spanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares called Sunday for an arms embargo on Israel. He also pressed for humanitarian aid to enter Gaza "massively, without conditions and without limits, and not controlled by Israel", describing the territory as humanity's "open wound". For more, FRANCE 24's correspondent in Spain, Sarah Morris.

title: What is the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, the organization whose head resigned?
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation is taking over the handling of aid despite objections from United Nations. The desperately needed supplies started flowing on a day that saw Israeli strikes kill at least 52 people in Gaza. The group said truckloads of food, it did not say how many. For more, FRANCE 24's International Affairs Editor, Philip Turle.

title: New aid system in Gaza begins operations after more than two months of blockade
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Little by little, some aid beginning to be distributed into Gaza. The US and Israel backed foundation given the task of supplying. It says it has now begun operations and that truckloads of food have already made it to distribution points, and some has already been handed out. No confirmation of that yet from the Palestinian side, but the foundation says moves will step up over the coming days. For more, France 24's correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky.

title: 'We must reduce our dependency against pesticides in French agriculture and across the EU'
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: French farmers disrupted highway traffic around Paris and rallied in front of parliament with their tractors on Monday, protesting against amendments filed by opposition lawmakers to a bill that would loosen environmental regulations on farming. The draft legislation proposes simplifying approvals for breeding facilities and irrigation reservoirs and re-authorising a banned neonicotinoid pesticide used in sugar beet cultivation that environmentalists say is harmful to bees. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Eve Irvine welcomes François Veillerette, Spokesperson for the French association Générations Futures and on the European Board of the Pesticide Action Network.

title: Victims of Le Scouarnec slam lack of action in France’s landmark child sex abuse case
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Former French surgeon Joël Le Scouarnec sexually abused 299 children over the course of 25 years, most of whom were under the age of 15, in one of the largest cases of child sexual abuse France has ever seen. As the trial comes to a close, his victims and organisations combatting violence against children wish the case had garnered more public attention or political action.

title: Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz launch French Open bids with straight-sets wins
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Favourites Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz made a strong start at the French Open with straight-sets wins in the first round, while world No. 4 Taylor Fritz is already out.

title: 🌟The Bright Side: Famed Sherpa guide breaks own record by climbing Mount Everest for 31st time
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Kami Rita Sherpa, a Nepali climber who has led expeditions up Mount Everest since 1994, broke his own record Tuesday by reaching the mountain's peak for the 31st time.

title: Opposition boycott gifts Venezuelan ruling party absolute majority
source: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro's ruling party swept regional and parliamentary elections, the country's electoral authority said on Monday, cementing an absolute majority in parliament until 2031 following a boycott by the opposition and crackdowns on dissent in the run-up to the vote.
